async_info.video_title: Crunching the numbers on key Brexit vote - BBC News
async_info.video_description:
The House of Commons will sit on Saturday to vote on the new Brexit deal proposed by UK prime minster Boris Johnson.
He needs 320 votes to win parliament's approval to leave the EU on 31 October, but does he have the numbers?
Please subscribe HERE http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

comment_content.original_script:
It's hard to over-estimate the importance of tomorrow's vote in Parliament. The result is on a knife-edge.

But it's clear to me that there is nothing in this Brexit deal to benefit our country. It will leave people worse off, jobs harder to find, businesses struggling and a race to the bottom as environmental and social standards are dumped.

It looks like a huge con on the British people because, if the vote succeeds, it will take us into a short transition period - giving people the completely false impression that there will be no impact on living standards, or workers’ rights and consumer protections outside the EU. Boris Johnson will doubtless use this opportunity to try to win an election and put in power a hard-right government which will then run down the clock to the end of the transition period so we end up leaving with no deal. One of the Conservative hardliners has already admitted that this is the plan.

Theresa May used to say "no deal is better than a bad deal". This deal is both: a bad deal with a no deal hidden inside.

I plan to speak both in the debate, and at the People's Vote rally outside. I hope you can be there.

(Caroline Lucas - Green MP for Brighton)

async_comment.comment_content_initial:
It's hard to over-estimate the importance of tomorrow's vote in Parliament. The result is on a knife-edge.
But it's clear to me that there is nothing in this Brexit deal to benefit our country. It will leave people worse off, jobs harder to find, businesses struggling and a race to the bottom as environmental and social standards are dumped.
It looks like a huge con on the British people because, if the vote succeeds, it will take us into a short transition period - giving people the completely false impression that there will be no impact on living standards, or workers’ rights and consumer protections outside the EU. Boris Johnson will doubtless use this opportunity to try to win an election and put in power a hard-right government which will then run down the clock to the end of the transition period so we end up leaving with no deal. One of the Conservative hardliners has already admitted that this is the plan.
Theresa May used to say "no deal is better than a bad deal". This deal is both: a bad deal with a no deal hidden inside.
I plan to speak both in the debate, and at the People's Vote rally outside. I hope you can be there.
(Caroline Lucas - Green MP for Brighton)

comment_content.original_script:
It's not a deal, it's a treaty & a shit one at that.
The idea that the EU won't give another extension, if we refuse this treaty is absurd & everyone knows it.
If this treaty is rejected we will end up with an extension & I am guessing an election.
One thing to be said in favour of the treaty is that it does get us out of the EU, no more extensions, no second referendum & no fear of article 50 being revoked to put us back to square one.
Scrapping this new treaty at a later date, would be a far simpler affair than Brexit.
